Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: EEG and EMG Human Model-Based Adaptive Control of a Dexterous Artificial Hand

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research goal of this award is to explore different methods for upper limb amputees to control dexterous artificial hands with brain waves. Biomedical signal processing techniques will be developed to enable this with a single, small recording electrode placed noninvasively on the amputees' heads. The recorded brain waves will be wirelessly transmitted to the hand in real time. A top-level controller will be developed to interpret the intent of the amputees while a low-level controller will be used to synchronize the dexterous grasp motions of the artificial hand. Algorithms will also be developed using tactile feedback from the fingertips to automatically prevent grasped objects from being accidentally dropped when they are transported or disturbed. Amputees will participate in a study to compare the newly developed artificial hand control techniques with brain waves to conventional control techniques with muscle signals during common tasks of daily life.


If successful, this research will result in a noninvasive and economic method for amputees to control a dexterous artificial hand with brain waves. This could substantially improve the functionality of prosthetic hands for many amputees. The use of minimal hardware will facilitate the clinical adoption of this technique and the autonomous low-level control algorithms will produce a brain machine interface that places a low cognitive burden on the operator. This research can also be readily applied to benefit many disabled people including stroke victims and quadriplegics and can positively impact other areas of robotics such as improvised explosive disarmament, underwater and space exploration, and rescue robotics. Underrepresented engineering students will benefit from being included in this research plan. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate engineering students will benefit from newly developed classes and laboratory exercises resulting from this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

A novel research platform was constructed comprising a robotic arm with a dexterous hand that was outfitted with sophisticated fingertip touch sensors. A real-time control interface was developed for the robotic arm and hand to be controlled by people using either brain waves measured by a custom cap with electrodes, or by muscle signals measured on the skin of the forearms of human subjects. Comparison studies were performed by limb-absent and able bodied human subjects to control the robotic arm and hand while performing common tasks of daily life. Results showed that the developed techniques hold a strong potential to alleviate the burden of integrating a dexterous artificial hand within the body image of upper limb-absent people. One prime contribution of this research is the development of human-inspired grasp reflexes that synchronize multiple joints of a robotic hand to facilitate mind or muscle control of a prosthesis by upper limb-absent people. This was enabled using a sensorized glove to measure human hand motions during typical tasks of daily life which were then mapped to the robotic system. The ability to distinguish between different sensations of touch was also demonstrated using neural network classifiers. The results are likely to positively impact the area of upper limb prosthetics and dexterous robotic grasping during tasks of daily living for upper limb amputees.

Broader Impacts:

This research project supported the education of 3 Ph.D. students (1 has graduated and 2 are continuing with their work) and 3 M.S. students who have graduated along with two undergraduate students.

The key findings and technology from this project have been broadly disseminated to general audiences through newspaper articles distributed to over 160,000 people and through highly visible media websites. The philanthropic goals of this project will hopefully inspire more people to pursue and support STEM fields.

The research products from this project are also the foundation of a new museum exhibit that is under development for a permanent display at the South Florida Science Center in West Palm Beach, FL. A prosthetic hand will be controlled by the muscle signals or brain waves of the museum patrons. This holds the potential to strongly impact young people during highly formative times in their lives. 

The findings in this project have been disseminated in high impact scientific journals and conferences. Algorithms were developed and presented in such a way that they could be easily integrated into commercially available prosthetic hands with minimal additional cost. Thus, current and future artificial hands could be significantly impacted by this research.

The developed grasp reflexes, control algorithms and classifiers in this project could also impact many areas of robotics such as surgical robotics, improvised explosive disarmament, and rescue robotics.
